III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS & CONCLUSIONS
A. Physical Description of Facility
This is a newly constructed, 32 bed, secure juvenile detention facility. It is divided
into four pods – each able to accommodate eight youth. Each pod consists of two
single rooms and three double rooms. Each room has an attached bathroom. Each
of the pods is able to accommodate a co-ed population, as census varies. Each
room has the ability to provide seclusion for one youth and is audio and video
monitored.
The facility also has an intake and mental health assessment area, medical/dental
area, a family services and visitation area, three classrooms and a computer lab, two
gymnasiums, a courtyard and outdoor recreation area, and two flexible living areas
that confine up to sixteen residents to a four room daytime living area.
There is good visibility between areas that allows staff to view not only their own pod
group, but to observe other pod groups to insure orderly operation throughout the
facility. All doors in the facility are electronic, with staff carrying key fobs to open
doors. The four exterior doors in the facility are not controlled by these fobs. A shift
supervisor area allows all pods to be observed simultaneously via cameras. Exterior
doors are controlled by the shift supervisor.
An Environmental Health Inspection on 10/9/2014 resulted in an “A” rating, as did
the Fire Safety Inspection conducted on 10/16/2014.
B. Program Description
The milieu of the facility utilizes policies and procedures from the old Transition
Center Facility, with very little change. Additionally, the teaching staff from the old
facility will continue to teach at the new facility. Program enhancements include
increased CMH supported assessments and treatment, more treatment resources
and group therapy, and increased partnering not only with Muskegon CMH, but also
the Intermediate School District, the juvenile court, and parents.
2

Food is prepared off site and transported to the facility in food warmers. Currently
the facility contracts with Canteen Food Service. Laundry Services will be provided
by the Muskegon County Jail.
The programming offered at the Transition Center will continue to be the Guided
Group Interaction (GGI) model. GGI Programming is offered to all residents and
consist s of group and individual skill development activities. General Guided Group
Interaction involves residents being taught to offer help and advice to each other
when a resident is showing inappropriate behaviors. Group assistance meetings are
called by staff when the informal resident assistance and advice does not resolve an
issue. Residents are also assessed to determine individual needs to be addressed
through four supplemental programming tracks [Mental Health, Building Respect for
Self & Others, Pre-Placement Preparation, and Community Living Preparation].
The Mental Health track will offer programming to youth diagnosed with significant
mental illnesses such as Depressive Illnesses, Reactive Attachment Disorder,
Anxiety Disorders, and Psychotic Illnesses. Programming will focus on mental health
education, coping with mental health symptoms, self-awareness skills, and building
healthy coping and relationship skills.
The Respect for Self & Others track will offer programming to youth exhibiting anti-
social and criminal behaviors. Programming will focus on the development of
empathy for others, self-awareness skills, victim impact awareness, giving of
yourself to others; repairing damaged relationships, and living productively in
community with others.
The Pre-Placement Preparation track will offer programming to youth preparing to
transfer to a residential placement in another facility. Programming will focus on the
development of age appropriate relationship/social/life skills, setting life-long goals,
learning what their pending placement will be like, feelings identification, and
developing coping skills.
The Community Living Preparation track will offer programming to youth preparing to
return to the local community. Programming will focus on the development of age
appropriate relationship/social/life skills, setting goals, development of a relapse
prevention plan, development of an emergency/danger response plan, development
of a community/family support plan.
3

C. Rule/Statutory Violations
The facility is in compliance with all licensing statutes and rules.
Consultation was offered by both consultants who inspected the facility. The
consultation related to the staffing ratio and a reasonable back up plan for staffing.
The current staffing ratio is 1:8 during awake hours and 1:11 while residents sleep.
The shift supervisor acting as back up to the four pods. While a variety of support
staff, administration, education staff, and CMH staff are present during the day; the
shift supervisor is the fifth staff in the facility and the only back up to one staff
working in each of the four pods after 5PM. This staffing configuration could be less
than safe for staff and residents because when the shift supervisor acts as a back up
staff during a crisis in one pod, or even relieves a staff for a break, no one monitors
cameras, is able to access outside doors, or provides support to the individual staff
supervising the other three pods. As the new facility expands from 22 beds to 32
beds, the potential for behavioral outbursts increases. As 22 or less residents will be
transferred to the new facility, it was recommended that staffing and backup
supports be reviewed prior to the facility reaching its full capacity.
IV. RECOMMENDATION
It is recommended that the seclusion rooms in this facility be approved and that this
secure child caring institution be issued a provisional license.
